Combining these last two results we have the following “ fundamental ” theorem concerning singularities of GBSHE functions. 
Theorem 4.  3.  With the exception of points on the x and у axes a necessary and sufficient condition for ii ( x,  y ) to be singular af z = ± a / A,  ±: ajk is for its 0-associate ^ /, to be singular at ka = or ka = — a. 
With this theorem one is able to transplant theorems about the location of sin gularities from classical function theory to the theory of solutions of the GBSHE.  We may list results such as those given in Section IV of [ 16 ]. A sample is given below.

V.  Bounds for GBSHE Functions
In this section we obtain growth properties of entire GBSHE functions,  with these results being independent of individual associates of the GBSHE functions.  We have first a definition and a lemma. 
Definition.  A GBSHE function u { Xy y ) with the series representation ( 2.  4 ) is said to be entire if and only if it has an infinite radius of convergence ^ that is ^ if and only if lim sup I a ^ n = 0.
